ArticleTitle.sentence: The gene encoding the periplasmic cyclophilin homologue, PPIase A, in Escherichia coli, is expressed from four promoters, three of which are activated by the cAMP-CRP complex and negatively regulated by the CytR repressor.

event.clue: The gene encoding the periplasmic cyclophilin homologue, PPIase A, in Escherichia coli, is expressed from four promoters, three of which are activated by the cAMP-CRP complex and negatively regulated by the CytR repressor.

The gene encoding the periplasmic cyclophilin homologue, PPIase A, in Escherichia coli, is expressed from four promoters, three of which are activated by the cAMP-CRP complex and negatively regulated by the CytR repressor.

AbstractText.sentence: The rot gene in Escherichia coli encodes PPIase A, a periplasmic peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase with homology to the cyclophilin family of proteins.

event.clue: The rot gene in Escherichia coli encodes PPIase A, a periplasmic peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase with homology to the cyclophilin family of proteins.

AbstractText.sentence: Here it is demonstrated that rot is expressed in a complex manner from four overlapping promoters and that the rot regulatory region is unusually compact, containing a close array of sites for DNA-binding proteins.

event.clue: Here it is demonstrated that rot is expressed in a complex manner from four overlapping promoters and that the rot regulatory region is unusually compact, containing a close array of sites for DNA-binding proteins.

AbstractText.sentence: The three most upstream rot promoters are activated by the global gene regulatory cAMP-CRP complex and negatively regulated by the CytR repressor protein.

event.clue: The three most upstream rot promoters are activated by the global gene regulatory cAMP-CRP complex and negatively regulated by the CytR repressor protein.
The three most upstream rot promoters are activated by the global gene regulatory cAMP-CRP complex and negatively regulated by the CytR repressor protein.

AbstractText.sentence: Activation of these three promoters occurs by binding of cAMP-CRP to two sites separated by 53 bp.

event.clue: Activation of these three promoters occurs by binding of cAMP-CRP to two sites separated by 53 bp.
Activation of these three promoters occurs by binding of cAMP-CRP to two sites separated by 53 bp.
Activation of these three promoters occurs by binding of cAMP-CRP to two sites separated by 53 bp.

AbstractText.sentence: Moreover, one of the cAMP-CRP complexes is involved in the activation of both a Class I and a Class II promoter.

event.clue: Moreover, one of the cAMP-CRP complexes is involved in the activation of both a Class I and a Class II promoter.
Moreover, one of the cAMP-CRP complexes is involved in the activation of both a Class I and a Class II promoter.

AbstractText.sentence: Repression takes place by the formation of a CytR/cAMP-CRP/DNA nucleoprotein complex consisting of the two cAMP-CRP molecules and CytR bound in between.

event.clue: Repression takes place by the formation of a CytR/cAMP-CRP/DNA nucleoprotein complex consisting of the two cAMP-CRP molecules and CytR bound in between.
Repression takes place by the formation of a CytR/cAMP-CRP/DNA nucleoprotein complex consisting of the two cAMP-CRP molecules and CytR bound in between.

AbstractText.sentence: The two regulators bind co-operatively to the DNA overlapping the three upstream promoters, simultaneously quenching the cAMP-CRP activator function.

event.clue: The two regulators bind co-operatively to the DNA overlapping the three upstream promoters, simultaneously quenching the cAMP-CRP activator function.

AbstractText.sentence: These results expand the CytR regulon to include a gene whose product has no known function in ribo- and deoxyribonucleoside catabolism or transport.
